definition: To expect something to happen; to look forward to; to act in advance of.
examples: We anticipate finishing the project by Friday.
She anticipated the question and prepared an answer.

extra.memory_tip: Anticipate = anti-cipate (before it happens, you’re ready).

definition: Having no money to pay what is owed; to make someone or something run out of money; a person declared unable to pay debts.
examples: The bankrupt company closed its stores. (adjective)
Poor planning can bankrupt a small business. (verb)

definition: Short in time or length; to give essential information quickly; a short summary or set of instructions.
examples: We had a brief meeting before class. (adjective)
The coach briefed the team on tactics. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Brief = be brief: keep it short.

definition: Quick and active; refreshing and cool.
examples: They set a brisk walking pace.
A brisk wind blew across the harbour.

extra.memory_tip: Brisk = brisket of speed—quick and sharp.

definition: A plan for how to spend money; to plan how to spend money; low-cost.
examples: We made a weekly food budget. (noun)
Remember to budget for transport costs. (verb)

definition: To take part in a contest or try to win against others.
examples: Our school will compete in the finals.
Many companies compete for customers.

definition: To make something more difficult or involved.
examples: Adding too many rules will complicate the game.
Missing data complicates the analysis.

definition: A result or change caused by something; to bring about or make happen.
examples: Lack of sleep has a negative effect on focus. (noun)
The council effected several road repairs. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Affect = action; effect = end result (and verb ‘effect’ means cause to happen).

definition: To make a mistake; to be wrong.
examples: To err is human; to learn is wise.
The map erred on the distance between towns.

extra.memory_tip: Err rhymes with ‘her’: when you err, own it and fix it.

definition: Something that influences a result; in maths, a number that divides another exactly; to include something in a plan or calculation.
examples: Weather is a key factor in farming. (noun)
Please factor travel time into the schedule. (verb)

extra.memory_tip: Factor = a fact that turns outcomes.

definition: Something that is very popular for a short time.
examples: That toy was last year’s fad.
Fads fade fast when the next thing arrives.

definition: To complain in an irritated way; a complaint.
examples: He’s always griping about the weather. (verb)
One common gripe is slow Wi-Fi. (noun)

definition: A natural skill or special way of doing something easily.
examples: She has a knack for fixing gadgets.
With practice you’ll get the knack of it.

extra.memory_tip: Knack = knack for knackering tricky tasks.

definition: Time when you are not working and can relax or enjoy activities.
examples: She reads for leisure in the evenings.
At your leisure, please review the draft.

definition: The only one of its kind; unlike anything else.
examples: Her painting style is unique.
Every fingerprint is unique.
